summary: The writers and directors are not trying to trick you. The actors aren’t trying to throw you off. There is no mysterious,...
body:
Jon and Dany is End Game

The writers and directors are not trying to trick you. The actors aren’t trying to throw you off. There is no mysterious, labyrinthan political maneuvering on Jon’s part. There is no alternate romantic interests for Jon or Dany. This is Fire and Ice. This is End Game.

“…our characters have had PARALLEL journeys…” Emilia Clarke, Variety, March 2019

“the two came together to shoot Jon and Daenerys’ slow-burn Season 7 romance” Variety, March 2019

“He believes in Jon Snow like a lot of people do and has gotten to know him in their travels together last season,” Glen says. “He thinks he’s a GOOD MATCH with Daenerys best interests in mind. It’s a complicated emotion, but I think he feels that they would be a GOOD UNIFICATION and he’s basically supportive.” Iain Glen, EW, March 2019

“…Jon Snow and Daenerys Targaryen met and fell in love…” EW, March 2019

“He’s wondering how smart of a move [Jon and Dany getting romantically involved is], because PASSION and politics don’t mix well. He knows the two of them getting together could be very dangerous.” Peter Dinklage, EW, March 2019

“She TRULY LOVES Jon. Were she to find out about his title, it would cut deep.“ Emilia Clarke, TV Insider, January 2019

"Jon is someone who plays by the book. HE CANNOT TELL A LIE. Finding out about Dany would be very hard for him.” Kit Harington, TV Insider, January 2019

“Dany and Jon take it to the NEXT LEVEL. In one night. On one boat. Heading for Winterfell. Heading for Season 8.” Emilia Clarke, HBO Asia, February 2019

“And they’re going back as not so secret lovers.” Kit Harington, HBO Asia, February 2019


“I think it’s an INEVITABILITY from about halfway through the season that Jon and Daenerys are gonna fall into bed together.” Kit Harington, HBO BTS Commentary, August 2017

“I think they both know it’s wrong. I think they both know it’s going to cause problems. But it’s that thing, when you suddenly feel that deeply about someone and you go through those events together, it’s like a runaway train. YOU CAN’T STOP IT FROM HAPPENING.” Kit Harington, HBO BTS Commentary 2017

“it described the fact that they were LOVEMAKING, but it didn’t go into great detail in terms of what was going on between them in that moment. We built in a moment between Kit [Harington] and Emilia [Clarke] where they stopped and looked into each other’s eyes. The intention from my point of view, and their point of view, too, is that THEY’RE DRIVEN BY PASSION into this. They don’t even fully understand what it’s all about and what the consequences of it are.” Jeremy Podeswa, The Hollywood Reporter, August 2018

“Knowing that Jon Snow and Daenerys would eventually fall in love just as the series revealed Jon’s true parentage, Djawadi tried to hint at his final theme, “Truth,” that would play during the pivotal finale scene.” EW, August 2017


“The trick with this theme is that it really had to be a LOVE THEME but when we played it in earlier episodes, you don’t want to give away the love too soon.” Ramon Djawadi, EE, August 2017

“…[I]n terms of going North to rescue them, a number of people there have different CLAIMS ON HER HEART…and then of course, there’s Jon Snow. You definitely get the sense that he’s become quite IMPORTANT to her in a short amount of time.” David Benioff, HBO Inside the Episode 7.06, August 2017

“I think that when she sees him return…that’s a big moment for her in terms of the way she FEELS FOR HIM.” D.B. Weiss, HBO Inside the Episode 7.06, August 2017

“I don’t think either one of them really knew exactly how powerful their feelings were towards each other in these moments. Just the notion of falling in love with someone involves weakness…but she feels that happening and he feels that happening for her. I think both of them are on unequal ground and especially because it’s with an equal.” David Benioff, HBO Inside the Episode 7.06, August 2017

“And to make it all ever more complicated, they’re starting to get ATTRACTED TO EACH OTHER…” David Benioff, HBO Inside the Episode 7.04, August 2017

“Jon looks to the people whose opinions he VALUES MOST: Davos. DANY.” Game of Thrones Script Ep 707, The Dragon and the Wolf

“Jon doesn’t quite smile because smiling would seem inappropriate. But still, that almost LOOKS LIKE A SMILE.” Game of Thrones Script Ep 707, The Dragon and the Wolf

“It is the most important relationship that either of them has. I think it is a really, really defining thing for them both.” Emilia Clarke, The New Paper, March 2019

“The King in the North found UNEXPECTED LOVE in Daenerys’ arms…” EW, March 2019

“The end of the world might be coming soon but at least he’s in love with somebody and knows who he is…” Kit Harington, EW, March 2019

title: Family
body:
Written for Day 5 of @jonsaspringblossoms based on the prompt CELEBRATION or REUNION or FAMILY

Sansa has it all. She has married her king, strong and gentle and brave. She is living the fairy tale life in Winterfell. And she has a beautiful baby boy. But an old promise to a red haired lady years ago threatens it all and Sansa fears there is no way to ever see her baby boy grow up.

Fairy Tale AU // Rumplestiltskin AU 

“What happened?” Jon rushed into the nursery. He had one hand on the hilt of his sword, but Sansa didn’t dare to look at him.

She simply pressed their baby boy as tightly to her chest as possible while she allowed her tears to roll down her cheeks and her neck. She should have known that this moment was coming. She she should have known that at some point the red lady would collect the price Sansa had agreed to pay her. Sansa should have known, the moment she discovered that she was pregnant, that she would not see her kid grow old.

“Sansa?” Jon wrapped an arm around her shoulders and his lips kissed her forehead. “You’re upset.”

Of course she was. She was happier than ever. She was married to the strong, gentle and brave man her father had promised her. She was holding a wonderful baby boy. She was living the life of her dreams. But it all came crashing down. It all came crashing down because of her own desperation to live without truly understanding the consequences.

“Talk to me, please.” Jon let his head rest on hers, but she doubted if he would still be this sweet and kind if he knew the truth, if he knew that she had promised a stranger her first born baby if that stranger would help her to take care of Ramsay Bolton.

“I can’t.” She shook her head. “You’ll hate me.” She sniffed and she pressed her wet lips on the forehead of her baby boy. “I hate me.”

Jon’s grip around her tightened and for a moment he simply rocked her back and forth without saying anything. “I won’t hate you.” Jon eventually whispered. “I can’t hate you. I love you too much for that.” His words were soothing, just like his voice, but Sansa knew he didn’t know what he was promising her.

Just like she hadn’t known what she had promised that stranger two years ago, when Ramsay Bolton had almost broken her and the wrong God had listened to her prayers. “She’ll come to get him.” Sansa swallowed. “When I was…” She closed her eyes and took a deep breath. She had never talked about this. She had wanted to forget about it and she had hoped that the stranger would do the same. “I didn’t just escape Ramsay.” She felt her heart racing in her chest, but in the back of her mind she heard her father and mother, telling her that the ugly truth was always better than a beautiful lie. “I got help.” She looked up at Jon and shook her head. “I didn’t know what I promised. I didn’t know, I swear.”

“What did you promise?” Jon spoke softly. “I really wanna help you, but you have to tell me everything.”

And so Sansa did. She told him about the red haired stranger who had shown up, assuring her that she could get Sansa out, that she could help Sansa escape the strong claws of the monster. She told him that the stranger had wanted the ring she had gotten from father to leave the door of her room unlocked. She told him that the stranger had taken the necklace she had gotten from mother to sedate the hungry dogs. She told him that the stranger had wanted her first born baby to make sure Ramsay would never come after her. And eventually she told him that she had agreed.

She had been foolish. She had been naive. She had been on the brink of dying. And she had given this beautiful baby boy up before she had even met him, without realising what she would truly be giving away.

“Why did you never tell me that?” Jon’s voice was calm, but she saw the pain in his eyes, the disappointment. “Why didn’t you trust me?”

“I did!” She replied. “I just wanted to forget. I wanted to forget about Ramsay and his dogs. I wanted to be happy. I thought…I hoped…” She wasn’t sure what she had thought and what she had hoped. “She’s coming back in three days. I tried to promise her gold and diamonds and brocade instead. I tried to promise her a title and a crown and a castle. But she still wanted the baby.” Her chest went up and down rapidly. “She said that nothing was worth as much as a baby with royal blood.”

Jon clenched his jaw, but he kept his arms firmly around her. The frown on his forehead deepened when he looked at his son, smiling and giggling in Sansa’s arms. “There has to be a way to stop her.” He hissed between his teeth. “There has to be something we can do.” He tensed all his muscles and he buried his nails in Sansa’s shoulders. “I can’t let her take our son away from us. I won’t. Over my dead body.”

“I’m sorry, Jon. I’m so sorry.” Sansa took a few deep breaths. “If I had known…”

“It’s not your fault.” Jon grabbed her chin and forced her to look at him. “If you hadn’t agreed, you would have died there. Ramsay would have…” Jon almost choked on the words. “That woman took advantage of a broken girl with nowhere to go and no other choice. She’s the one who was wrong. And she’ll pay the price for it.”

Sansa bit her lip. “She can’t be killed, Jon.” Sansa shook her head once more. “I tried to threaten her, but she told me that the only thing that could kill her, was her name.” She felt her shoulders shaking. “I don’t know her name. She says no one does.”

“She’s wrong.” Jon used his hands to wipe the tears from her cheeks. “We have Bran. Bran knows everything. Bran sees everything. He can find her name. If he has to, he can find the moment her parents gave it to her. And when she returns we will use it to destroy her.”

Sansa focussed on her breathing. In and out. In and out. She knew that she wouldn’t fully calm down until that red woman was destroyed and gone. Until their baby boy was safe. Until they had cleaned up her own mess. But Jon had given her something she had thought she had lost.

Hope.

Bran could figure this out.

That name would destroy the red lady.

And Sansa, Jon and their baby boy would get their happily ever after.

“I can’t.” She shook her head. “You’ll hate me.” She sniffed and she pressed her wet lips on the forehead of her baby boy. “I hate me.”

Jon’s grip around her tightened and for a moment he simply rocked her back and forth without saying anything. “I won’t hate you.” Jon eventually whispered. “I can’t hate you. Fairy Tale AU // Rumplestiltskin AU 

“What happened?” Jon rushed into the nursery. He had one hand on the hilt of his sword, but Sansa didn’t dare to look at him.

She simply pressed their baby boy as tightly to her chest as possible while she allowed her tears to roll down her cheeks and her neck. She should have known that this moment was coming. She she should have known that at some point the red lady would collect the price Sansa had agreed to pay her. Sansa should have known, the moment she discovered that she was pregnant, that she would not see her kid grow old.

“Sansa?” Jon wrapped an arm around her shoulders and his lips kissed her forehead. “You’re upset.”

Of course she was. She was happier than ever. She was married to the strong, gentle and brave man her father had promised her. She was holding a wonderful baby boy. She was living the life of her dreams. But it all came crashing down. It all came crashing down because of her own desperation to live without truly understanding the consequences.

“Talk to me, please.” Jon let his head rest on hers, but she doubted if he would still be this sweet and kind if he knew the truth, if he knew that she had promised a stranger her first born baby if that stranger would help her to take care of Ramsay Bolton.

“I can’t.” She shook her head. “You’ll hate me.” She sniffed and she pressed her wet lips on the forehead of her baby boy. “I hate me.”

Jon’s grip around her tightened and for a moment he simply rocked her back and forth without saying anything. “I won’t hate you.” Jon eventually whispered. “I can’t hate you. I love you too much for that.” His words were soothing, just like his voice, but Sansa knew he didn’t know what he was promising her.

[[MORE]]

Just like she hadn’t known what she had promised that stranger two years ago, when Ramsay Bolton had almost broken her and the wrong God had listened to her prayers. “She’ll come to get him.” Sansa swallowed. “When I was…” She closed her eyes and took a deep breath. She had never talked about this. She had wanted to forget about it and she had hoped that the stranger would do the same. “I didn’t just escape Ramsay.” She felt her heart racing in her chest, but in the back of her mind she heard her father and mother, telling her that the ugly truth was always better than a beautiful lie. “I got help.” She looked up at Jon and shook her head. “I didn’t know what I promised. I didn’t know, I swear.”

“What did you promise?” Jon spoke softly. “I really wanna help you, but you have to tell me everything.”

And so Sansa did. She told him about the red haired stranger who had shown up, assuring her that she could get Sansa out, that she could help Sansa escape the strong claws of the monster. She told him that the stranger had wanted the ring she had gotten from father to leave the door of her room unlocked. She told him that the stranger had taken the necklace she had gotten from mother to sedate the hungry dogs. She told him that the stranger had wanted her first born baby to make sure Ramsay would never come after her. And eventually she told him that she had agreed.

She had been foolish. She had been naive. She had been on the brink of dying. And she had given this beautiful baby boy up before she had even met him, without realising what she would truly be giving away.

“Why did you never tell me that?” Jon’s voice was calm, but she saw the pain in his eyes, the disappointment. “Why didn’t you trust me?”

“I did!” She replied. “I just wanted to forget. I wanted to forget about Ramsay and his dogs. I wanted to be happy. I thought…I hoped…” She wasn’t sure what she had thought and what she had hoped. “She’s coming back in three days. I tried to promise her gold and diamonds and brocade instead. I tried to promise her a title and a crown and a castle. But she still wanted the baby.” Her chest went up and down rapidly. “She said that nothing was worth as much as a baby with royal blood.”

Jon clenched his jaw, but he kept his arms firmly around her. The frown on his forehead deepened when he looked at his son, smiling and giggling in Sansa’s arms. “There has to be a way to stop her.” He hissed between his teeth. “There has to be something we can do.” He tensed all his muscles and he buried his nails in Sansa’s shoulders. “I can’t let her take our son away from us. I won’t. Over my dead body.”

“I’m sorry, Jon. I’m so sorry.” Sansa took a few deep breaths. “If I had known…”

“It’s not your fault.” Jon grabbed her chin and forced her to look at him. “If you hadn’t agreed, you would have died there. Ramsay would have…” Jon almost choked on the words. “That woman took advantage of a broken girl with nowhere to go and no other choice. She’s the one who was wrong. And she’ll pay the price for it.”

Sansa bit her lip. “She can’t be killed, Jon.” Sansa shook her head once more. “I tried to threaten her, but she told me that the only thing that could kill her, was her name.” She felt her shoulders shaking. “I don’t know her name. She says no one does.”

“She’s wrong.” Jon used his hands to wipe the tears from her cheeks. “We have Bran. Bran knows everything. Bran sees everything. He can find her name. If he has to, he can find the moment her parents gave it to her. And when she returns we will use it to destroy her.”

Sansa focussed on her breathing. In and out. In and out. She knew that she wouldn’t fully calm down until that red woman was destroyed and gone. Until their baby boy was safe. Until they had cleaned up her own mess. But Jon had given her something she had thought she had lost.

Hope.

Bran could figure this out.

That name would destroy the red lady.

And Sansa, Jon and their baby boy would get their happily ever after.

body:
Thoughts on Jonerys

I’m still not sure wether or not I ship Jonerys I feel like I have valid reasons not too but reasons to ship them. Idk if it’s just me but the relationship seems so forced to me that it’s hard to be believable considering she told him to bend the knee every 5 minutes. Hell I even lost a lot of love for Dany throughout the seasons because sometimes she was so entitled. It’s just that they act like Dany and Jon has these monumental in-depth moments when they didn’t.

summary: There’s nothing really new in Kit’s interview with Variety. But here is a snippet of him talking about the role of politics in...
body:
There’s nothing really new in Kit’s interview with Variety. But here is a snippet of him talking about the role of politics in Game of Thrones.

“The show’s always been about power. Power and family.”

And I agree! As much fun as the magic, dragons and Others bring to the show they are not the heart of the story. Honestly, it would be quite bland without the struggle for power between the characters, and families in the show.

The battle scenes will be exciting to watch and I commend the cast and crew for the work they put into them. But I will be more invested in the scenes that will showcase the power and family dynamics.

After two years I can’t wait to see how these themes play out on screen.

Give me inner turmoil.

Give me conflict between characters due to clashing values and goals.

Give me duty versus want.

Give me a well earned resolution to a story whose main focus has been power and family.

In conclusion, GIVE ME ALL THE ANGST.

There’s nothing really new in Kit’s interview with Variety. But here is a snippet of him talking about the role of politics in Game of Thrones.

“The show’s always been about power. Power and family.”

And I agree! As much fun as the magic, dragons and Others bring to the show they are not the heart of the story. Honestly, it would be quite bland without the struggle for power between the characters, and families in the show.

The battle scenes will be exciting to watch and I commend the cast and crew for the work they put into them. But I will be more invested in the scenes that will showcase the power and family dynamics.

After two years I can’t wait to see how these themes play out on screen.

Give me inner turmoil.

Give me conflict between characters due to clashing values and goals.

Give me duty versus want.

Give me a well earned resolution to a story whose main focus has been power and family.

In conclusion, GIVE ME ALL THE ANGST.

summary: I think Daenerys that the way has been judged by fans has everything to do with the way David and Dan have written her character...
question: I think Daenerys that the way has been judged by fans has everything to do with the way David and Dan have written her character during the whole series. People who have read books likes us know she is too different from the series' Dany, and we understand many things that casual watches don't. And Dave and Dan have not only make mistakes with Dany, but with other characters too. It is the reason why too many ASOIAF readers just don't like the show.
answer:
Hello anon,

I just answered a somewhat similar questions. I would agree that the writing for the show hasn’t always been great. There been more than a few missteps. It is especially hard given that it’s an adaptation of a involved book series that is currently incomplete. 

Because it is an adaptations many things had to be changed or eliminated, no one was ever going to be happy about what they took away from the books. That’s just the way it is. However, even with the deficiencies in the writing team, it’s still the most popular show on television and one of the best in history. Game of Thrones literally changed television. That’s just a fact. So yeah, it’s not always great, sometimes it’s terrible, but most of the time they are pretty good and even great.

TTFN

summary:
I LOVE the dynamics between the Stark siblings:
-Jon and Robb grew up together, they are best friends. And they are an example...
body:
I LOVE the dynamics between the Stark siblings:

-Jon and Robb grew up together, they are best friends. And they are an example to the youngers.

-Jon and Arya, his little sister. His heart. They have a connection none other character has. They are soulmates.

-Bran and Arya, very close in age. I cannot count how many times Bran remembers Arya, misses her, looks up to her, … They ressemble Lyanna and Benjen quite a lot.

-Rickon and everyone, but specially Bran and Arya. He is their baby brother. They protect him like mama wolves (lol Arya punched Jon for scaring him, cutest thing ever).

-Bran and Jon. Bran saved Jon (as Summer) when he left the wildings. And Jon braved Catelyn to say goodbye to an unconcious Bran.

-Arya and Robb, she looks up to him so much. They were so close at the Twins and yet so far thank the old gods for that, I cannot think about how things would have been if Arya had been recognised.

-Sansa and Arya, as different as the sun and the moon, and yet they have a connection.

Pretty sure I’m missing sth, but this sums it up.

summary: Jon Snow and Daenerys Targaryen met and fell in love...
body:
Jon Snow and Daenerys Targaryen met and fell in love…

New article from Entertainment Weekly where the writers discuss criticism over the rushed pace of season 7. According to co-executive producer Bryan Cogman: “We made a choice to just get on with it last season.” Also: “You obviously don’t want any criticism of any kind… but with all the things we were balancing to set things up for season 8, sometimes we had to speed things up within episodes.”

So yes, Jonerys may have felt rushed (although, personally, I thought the show handled it perfectly) but clearly there’s no underlining twist or insincerity between Jon and Dany’s relationship. It’s just a man and a woman in love, as most of us have known all along.
